page.title: 10ECOLOGY IN MARSHFIELD
page.content: Flora and fauna are typical of the South Cotswolds. Interesting flora include the Meadow Saffron, plentiful in the autumn, and the Bee Orchid, at one site only. Birds are those of an upland area: Kestrel, Sparrow Hawk, Buzzard, Magpie and Skylark. Grey Partridge and Pheasant are common most years. A local rarity is the Quail, present from May to October, breeding being restricted by farming methods and the wet summer of 1985. A rare visitor is the Hobby. Among the larger mammals are the Red Fox and the Badger, both fairly common despite hunting & persecution. Recently the Roe Deer has spread into the area from Wiltshire, and an exotic species of deer, the Muntjac, is found at times. Winter can be severe, with roads often blocked by drifting snow. Noise from military planes can be a nuisance.
